question: Which gas forms clouds when it condenses in the atmosphere?

content.source_1: In Earth’s lower atmosphere, familiar clouds form when humid air cools and water vapor condenses onto aerosols, producing tiny liquid water droplets that collectively become visible as a cloud.
content.source_2: Water vapor is the gaseous phase of H2O; when it condenses under saturation, it transitions to liquid water droplets.
content.source_3: Polar stratospheric clouds (PSCs), also called nacreous clouds, are recognized cloud types that form in Earth’s winter polar stratosphere.
content.source_4: Type Ib PSCs consist of supercooled liquid droplets made of nitric acid–water–sulfuric acid solution; these droplets form when gaseous nitric acid (HNO3) condenses onto existing aerosols under very cold stratospheric conditions.
content.source_5: In cloud physics, a cloud is any visible aggregate of suspended condensed-phase particles (liquid droplets or ice) in an atmosphere, regardless of chemical composition.
content.source_6: Tropospheric conditions frequently reach saturation with respect to water vapor, making condensation of water vapor the dominant mechanism for the formation of common low and mid-level clouds.
